metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: CSS Horizontal Navigation Bar
Horizontal Navigation Bar
There are two ways to create a horizontal navigation bar. Using inline or floating list items.
content.html: There are two ways to create a horizontal navigation bar. Using inline or floating list items.

content.text: Inline List Items
One way to build a horizontal navigation bar is to specify the <li> elements as inline, in addition to the "standard" code from the previous page:
content.html: One way to build a horizontal navigation bar is to specify the <li> elements as inline, in addition to the "standard" code from the previous page:

content.code_html:
li {
  display: inline;
}

content.text: Example explained:
Floating List Items
Another way of creating a horizontal navigation bar is to float the <li> elements, and specify a layout for the navigation links:
content.html: Another way of creating a horizontal navigation bar is to float the <li> elements, and specify a layout for the navigation links:

content.code_html:
li {
  float: left;
}

a {
  display: block;
  padding: 8px;
  background-color: #dddddd;
}

content.text: Example explained:
Tip: Add the background-color to <ul> instead of each <a> element if you want a full-width background color:
content.html: Tip: Add the background-color to <ul> instead of each <a> element if you want a full-width background color:

content.code_html:
ul {
  background-color: #dddddd;
}

content.text: Horizontal Navigation Bar Examples
Create a basic horizontal navigation bar with a dark background color and change the background color of the links when the user moves the mouse over them:
content.html: Create a basic horizontal navigation bar with a dark background color and change the background color of the links when the user moves the mouse over them:

syntaxHighlighting.text: /* Change the link color to #111 (black) on hover */

syntax_highlighting.text: /* Change the link color to #111 (black) on hover */

content.code_html:
ul {
  list-style-type: none;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  overflow: hidden;
  background-color: #333;
}

li {
  float: left;
}

li a {
  display: block;
  color: white;
  text-align: center;
  padding: 14px 16px;
  text-decoration: none;
}

/* Change the link color to #111 (black) on hover */
li a:hover {
  background-color: #111;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: /* Change the link color to #111 (black) on hover */

content.text: Active/Current Navigation Link
Add an "active" class to the current link to let the user know which page he/she is on:
content.html: Add an "active" class to the current link to let the user know which page he/she is on:

content.code_html:
.active {
  background-color: #04AA6D;
}

content.text: Right-Align Links
Right-align links by floating the list items to the right ( float:right; ):
content.html: Right-align links by floating the list items to the right (float:right;):

content.code:
• Home
    •  
  • News
    •  
  • Contact
  • About
content.code_html:
<ul>
  <li><a href="#home">Home</a></li>
  <li><a href="#news">News</a></li>
  <li><a href="#contact">Contact</a></li>
  <li style="float:right"><a class="active" href="#about">About</a></li>
</ul>

content.text: Border Dividers
Add the border-right property to <li> to create link dividers:
content.html: Add the border-right property to <li> to create link dividers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
/* Add a gray right border to all list items, except the last item 
(last-child) */

syntax_highlighting.text:
/* Add a gray right border to all list items, except the last item 
(last-child) */

content.code_html:
/* Add a gray right border to all list items, except the last item (last-child) */
li {
  border-right: 1px solid #bbb;
}

li:last-child {
  border-right: none;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
/* Add a gray right border to all list items, except the last item 
(last-child) */

content.text: Fixed Navigation Bar
Make the navigation bar stay at the top or the bottom of the page, even when the user scrolls the page:
content.html: Make the navigation bar stay at the top or the bottom of the page, even when the user scrolls the page:

content.code_html:
ul {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

ul {
  position: fixed;
  bottom: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

content.text: Note: Fixed position might not work properly on mobile devices.
content.html: Note: Fixed position might not work properly on mobile devices.

content.text: Gray Horizontal Navbar
An example of a gray horizontal navigation bar with a thin gray border:
content.html: An example of a gray horizontal navigation bar with a thin gray border:

content.code_html:
ul {
  border: 1px solid #e7e7e7;
  background-color: #f3f3f3;
}

li a {
  color: #666;
}

content.text: Sticky Navbar
Add position: sticky; to <ul> to create a sticky navbar.
content.html: Add position: sticky; to <ul> to create a sticky navbar.

content.text: A sticky element toggles between relative and fixed, depending on the scroll position. It is positioned relative until a given offset position is met in the viewport - then it "sticks" in place (like position:fixed).
content.html: A sticky element toggles between relative and fixed, depending on the scroll position. It is positioned relative until a given offset position is met in the viewport - then it "sticks" in place (like position:fixed).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
ul {  position: -webkit-sticky; /* Safari */  
  position: sticky;  top: 0;}

content.code:
ul {  position: -webkit-sticky; /* Safari */
position: sticky;  top: 0;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
ul {  position: -webkit-sticky; /* Safari */  
  position: sticky;  top: 0;}

content.code_html:
ul {
  position: -webkit-sticky; /* Safari */
  position: sticky;
  top: 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
ul {  position: -webkit-sticky; /* Safari */  
  position: sticky;  top: 0;}

content.text: Note: Internet Explorer does not support sticky positioning. Safari requires the -webkit- prefix (see example above). You must also specify at least one of top , right , bottom or left for sticky positioning to work.
content.html: Note: Internet Explorer does not support sticky positioning. Safari requires the -webkit- prefix (see example above). You must also specify at least one of top, right, bottom or left for sticky positioning to work.
